2.1 1.1 What is Nutrigenomics (Statistical View)
This chapter introduces nutrigenomics from a statistical perspective, motivates key experimental designs, and reviews the types of data used in this field. It concludes with practical guidance for setting up R and the course repository.
Nutrigenomics explores how dietary patterns influence gene expression, epigenetic marks, and metabolic outcomes. Statistically, we ask:

title: 2Â  1. Overview
text:
2.2 1.2 Why Design Matters
Design choice determines causal interpretability and power.

Caseâ€“control (retrospective): efficient for rare outcomes, common in geneâ€“diet interaction studies.
Example: Hoang et al., JAMA Network Open (2024). DOI: 10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2024.0465
Cross-sectional: exposure and outcome measured simultaneously, used for exploratory omicsâ€“diet associations.
Example: Do et al., Int J Epidemiol. (2021). DOI: 10.1093/ije/dyaa215
Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT): causal inference via randomization; typical for genotypeâ€‘based dietary advice.
Example: Horne et al., BMC Public Health (2019). DOI: 10.1186/s12889-019-6621-8

Note: Randomization removes confounding in expectation; observational designs require covariate adjustment and sensitivity analyses.

title: 2Â  1. Overview
text:
2.4 1.4 Types of Data in Nutrigenomics

Omics data (gene expression, methylation, metabolomics)

Example: EWAS of diet quality â€” DOI: 10.1093/ije/dyaa215

Clinical data (anthropometry, blood lipids, disease outcomes)

Example: NOW Trial â€” DOI: 10.1186/s12889-019-6621-8

Dietary data (FFQs, 24h recalls, dietary indices)

Example: Zheng et al., PLOS ONE (2020). DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0230669


Each has unique preprocessing and error structures (e.g., normalization for omics, energy adjustment for dietary data).

3.3 2.3 Basic R Commands
# Install packages
install.packages("tidyverse")

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

# Read a CSV file
d <- read_csv("data/diet_gene_example.csv")

# Inspect structure
glimpse(d)

# Quick summary
d %>% group_by(case_status) %>% summarize(mean_BMI = mean(BMI, na.rm = TRUE), n = n())

3.3.1 Exercise
Run each line, explain what it does, and identify one potential data quality issue (missing values, unrealistic ranges, etc.).
